column4: I'm trying to format an external drive manually, and it either can't open the unformatted drive or it can't find it
Can someone help me
external drives are usually always FAT32, trying to partition them and format them with other file systems maybe troublesome, or so I've read.
No, I've wiped the entire drive.  Its unformatted at this point
for some reason the command "fdisk -l | grep '^Disk' doesn't do anything for me
run it with sudo, "sudo fdisk -l"
So its possible I'm looking at the wrong partition
partitioning and formating is rather easy with Gparted, how can anybody have problems with it.
All right, there we go.  According to the terminal the device apparently doesn't exist and can't open
plug it to a different USB port, reconnect multiple times, see the output of "dmesg"
I tried using Gparted and had the same issues,  It could reformat, but when it came to making the filesystem it insisted the device didn't exist.
It said it found a new device at 3 and is waiting for it to settle
it is in some way different your external drive? Check the brand name and model in the forums for any clue.
The hard drive was originally that of my old Pc, I just gutted it and turned it into an external hard drive
I'm trying to do it in Gparted again.
maybe it's dead. Once a Hard drive didn't show up anymore and I tried many things. But eventually realized not even the BIOS detected it. So I ditched it.
I'm considering the possibility.  The only thing that makes me hesitate is the fact that it worked fine as an external hard drive until I tried to change the filesystem
I just wish there was a clear sign
yeah. I tried mine in an old PC and then on a newer one, and it was fine. And then it simply dies. No way to tell.
It created an empty partition and is now setting the partition type to /dev/sdb1
Ugh.  Same issue....
you meant the partition type is ext3. /dev/sdb1 is the node point.
No, the patition type is ext2.  It succeeded in that step then said: mkfs.ext2 /dev/sdb1 could not stat /dev/sdb1 --- No such file or directory
use a live CD to do it, or Windows, I don't know. If you just want to allocate the space use whatever it takes, then try to create the filesystem.
